content.webTitle: Sydney Opera House: The Opera – as new as you're going to get in 2016

fields.headline: Sydney Opera House: The Opera – as new as you're going to get in 2016
fields.bodyText: Kate Miller-Heidke, Lally Katz and Iain Grandage’s multiple Helpmann award-winning The Rabbits have bred and spread from Perth to Melbourne and now to Sydney, where their furry hides will be welcomed harbourside this summer. Meanwhile, Bell Shakespeare’s retiring founder, John Bell, will give audiences another take on Bizet’s much-reproduced Carmen, but “with punch”, we’re told (it’s surely been punchy before), and the Australian playwright and director Michael Gow will reimagine Bizet’s much earlier opera, The Pearlfishers, contemplating the history behind its cultural stereotypes. All three productions should capably deliver the goods. But what of the new, large-scale, “Sydney-identified” opera that Opera Australia’s artistic director Lyndon Terracini hinted at several months ago as part of the company’s 60th anniversary season in 2016? Unveiled on Tuesday, that would appear to be Sydney Opera House: The Opera, a new production and a new name for The Eighth Wonder, an opera by the Australian composer Alan John with a libretto by Dennis Watkins. But it’s hardly new, having been staged inside the Opera House in 1995 then shelved for 20 years. For just five performances in October and November 2016, it will tell a story of political grandstanding, budget overruns, the sacking of architect Jørn Utzon and the narrowing of his vision for the Sydney landmark, despite its engineering magnificence and its postcard-perfect surface. A very Australian story of political expediency, then, and how appropriate it will be performed this time on the steps, showing off the Opera House’s best bit: its sails. No risk of an audience contemplating the Joan Sutherland theatre’s wings, which allow only a slither of space between a dancer pirouetting off stage and the wall, or those poor musicians cramped in the confines of the orchestra pit. There’s one big reason why Neil Armfield’s acclaimed take on Wagner’s Ring Cycle is returning to Melbourne, in November and December 2016, and not to Sydney: it wouldn’t fit in the Opera House. The building’s part closure in 2017 for maintenance will present a new set of problems for Opera Australia but could solve some old ones. Though as David McVicar told the Sydney Morning Herald this week: “It won’t fix what should be fixed ... the orchestra pit is still a problem and back stage access is not ideal.” It’s still disappointing, however, that no other new work based on an Australian story will be presented either in Sydney or at the Arts Centre Melbourne in 2016. It was already a given that the much-lauded The Rabbits, based on John Marsden and artist Shaun Tan’s picture book, would get a Sydney outing, as it will in January. The Rabbits sold 5,000 tickets at its Perth festival premiere, and is certain to be a drawcard at the Melbourne festival in October. Sadly, it’s more than five years since Opera Australia presented a brand new work: Brett Dean’s $2m Bliss, based on Peter Carey’s novel, in 2010. But as Terracini told Guardian Australia in March, only 10,000 seats were sold across Bliss’s Sydney and Melbourne seasons combined. Around the same time, Lindy Hume, the artistic director of Queensland Opera, insisted: “If it’s an Australian creative team, it’s an Australian work.” That definition acknowledges, say, the antipodean flourish Bell and co will bring to Carmen, and Gow to The Pearlfishers. But are these our stories, reflecting and questioning our experiences back to us as Australians? Sydney Opera House: The Opera’s theme of compromised vision may indeed reveal something flawed in the nation’s uneasy relationship to culture. But its self-referential and literal landscape means it won’t join the canon of Puccini, Verdi, Rossini and Bizet – endlessly reproduced. Why not bring back Voss, first staged in 1986 and based on the Patrick White novel, or help the State Opera of South Australia realise its plans to stage an opera of Tim Winton’s Cloudstreet? The 2016 Opera on the Harbour will be Puccini’s Turandot, directed by the Chinese artist Chen Shi-Zheng. Cue the Sydney flourish of fireworks, as per the Destination NSW brief: we give bang for our opera buck, even though those opera extravaganzas probably lose money for their undisclosed cost. Regrettably, the national opera review putting the artistic co-operation between the nation’s big and small opera companies and the creation of new works under the microscope seems to have disappeared from sight. The review, which examined four opera companies in receipt of federal funds – Opera Australia, State Opera of South Australia, West Australian Opera and Opera Queensland – now looks unlikely to publish its report until the end of 2015, several months beyond its original projected deadline. It seems George Brandis’s National Program for Excellence in the Arts is taking up all the government’s creative thinking space right now. Which is somewhat less than excellent.
